Paper: [Causally estimating the effect of YouTube's recommender system using counterfactual bots](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2308.10398.pdf)
Why should we care: One of the first studies to estimate the effects of the YouTube recommender system on radicalisation using counterfactual viewing series, using bots.
It introduces E-BERT, which aligns Wikipedia2Vec entity vectors with BERT's wordpiece vector space, enabling the use of entity vectors as if they were wordpiece vectors.
The paper introduces a marginalization technique to performance inference at prediction time for a trained marked temporal point process when presented with mark censoring.

Paper: [Causality Guided Disentanglement for Cross-Platform Hate Speech Detection](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2308.02080.pdf)
Why should we care: The paper introduces a hate speech detection model that uses a VAE to extract causal embeddings separated into platform independent features useful for predicting presence of hate, and platform dependent features useful for predicting the target of hate.

Paper: No reading due to public holiday
Adaptable Transfer Learning Models for Online Misinformation Detection
[Demystifying embedding spaces using large language models](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.04475)
Why should we care: This paper introduces a novel framework to interpret and interact embedding vectors by leveraging the power of LLMs.

Paper: [SoK: A Framework for Unifying At-Risk User Research](https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/stamp/stamp.jsp?tp=&arnumber=9833643)
Why should we care: Paper linked during the [Google Trust and Safety Awards](https://research.google/programs-and-events/trust-safety-research/) information session and strongly suggested everyone read. They really liked how it understood ‘at risk’ users, and also the human and technical considerations it made.

Paper: Dry run of the CMT II Keynote presentation.
Why should we care: The dry-run will happen in the [UTS Data Arena facility](https:/dataarena.net/) –  a 360° data visualisation facility designed for collaborative experiences.

Paper: [Temporal dynamics of coordinated online behavior: Stability, archetypes, and influence](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2307038121)
Why should we care: This paper examines temporal change in online coordinated communities and introduces temporal multiplex networks as a means of dynamically identifying communities engaging in coordinated behaviour leading up to elections in the UK and the US.

Paper: [From Word Models to World Models: Translating from Natural Language to the Probabilistic Language of Thought](https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12672)
Why should we care: This paper takes you to the world model. How does language inform our downstream thinking? In particular how do humans make meaning from language--and how can we leverage a theory of linguistic meaning to build machines that think in more human-like ways? In this paper they propose rational meaning construction a computational framework for language-informed thinking that combines neural language models with probabilistic models for rational inference.

Paper: [Unmasking the Web of Deceit: Uncovering Coordinated Activity to Expose Information Operations on Twitter](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2310.09884)
Why should we care: This paper delves into the detection of key players driving IOs by employing similarity graphs constructed from behavioral pattern data.
